children.help:
The prefix/path that is used to call the toolchain. The default setting assumes
a crosstool-ng gcc setup that is in your PATH.
children.name: TOOLPREFIX
children.title: Compiler toolchain path/prefix

children.help:
The executable name/path that is used to run python. On some systems Python 2.x
may need to be invoked as python2.

(Note: This option is used with the GNU Make build system only, not idf.py
or CMake-based builds.)
children.name: PYTHON
children.title: Python 2 interpreter

children.help:
Adds --warn-undefined-variables to MAKEFLAGS. This causes make to
print a warning any time an undefined variable is referenced.

This option helps find places where a variable reference is misspelled
or otherwise missing, but it can be unwanted if you have Makefiles which
depend on undefined variables expanding to an empty string.
children.name: MAKE_WARN_UNDEFINED_VARIABLES
children.title: 'make' warns on undefined variables

children.help: Specify how much output to see in bootloader logs.
children.name: LOG_BOOTLOADER_LEVEL
children.title: Bootloader log verbosity

children.help:
This value is ignored unless flash mode is set to QIO or QOUT *and* the SPI flash pins have been
overriden by setting the efuses SPI_PAD_CONFIG_xxx.

When this is the case, the Efuse config only defines 3 of the 4 Quad I/O data pins. The WP pin (aka ESP32
pin "SD_DATA_3" or SPI flash pin "IO2") is not specified in Efuse. That pin number is compiled into the bootloader
instead.

The default value (GPIO 7) is correct for WP pin on ESP32-D2WD integrated flash.
children.name: BOOTLOADER_SPI_WP_PIN
children.title: SPI Flash WP Pin when customising pins via efuse (read help)

children.help:
If this option is enabled, and VDDSDIO LDO is set to 1.8V (using EFUSE
or MTDI bootstrapping pin), bootloader will change LDO settings to
output 1.9V instead. This helps prevent flash chip from browning out
during flash programming operations.

This option has no effect if VDDSDIO is set to 3.3V, or if the internal
VDDSDIO regulator is disabled via efuse.
children.name: BOOTLOADER_VDDSDIO_BOOST
children.title: VDDSDIO LDO voltage

children.help:
The selected GPIO will be configured as an input with internal pull-up enabled.
To trigger a factory reset, this GPIO must be pulled low on reset.
Note that GPIO34-39 do not have an internal pullup and an external one must be provided.
children.name: BOOTLOADER_NUM_PIN_FACTORY_RESET
children.title: Number of the GPIO input for factory reset

children.help: The device will boot from "factory" partition (or OTA slot 0 if no factory partition is present) after a factory reset.
children.name: BOOTLOADER_OTA_DATA_ERASE
children.title: Clear OTA data on factory reset (select factory partition)

children.help:
Allows customers to select which data partitions will be erased while factory reset.

Specify the names of partitions as a comma-delimited with optional spaces for readability. (Like this: "nvs, phy_init, ...")
Make sure that the name specified in the partition table and here are the same.
Partitions of type "app" cannot be specified here.
children.name: BOOTLOADER_DATA_FACTORY_RESET
children.title: Comma-separated names of partitions to clear on factory reset

children.help:
Allows to reset the device to factory settings:
- clear one or more data partitions;
- boot from "factory" partition.
The factory reset will occur if there is a GPIO input pulled low while device starts up.
See settings below.
children.name: BOOTLOADER_FACTORY_RESET
children.title: GPIO triggers factory reset

children.help:
The selected GPIO will be configured as an input with internal pull-up enabled.
To trigger a test app, this GPIO must be pulled low on reset.
After the GPIO input is deactivated and the device reboots, the old application will boot.
(factory or OTA[x]).
Note that GPIO34-39 do not have an internal pullup and an external one must be provided.
children.name: BOOTLOADER_NUM_PIN_APP_TEST
children.title: Number of the GPIO input to boot TEST partition

children.help:
Allows to run the test app from "TEST" partition.
A boot from "test" partition will occur if there is a GPIO input pulled low while device starts up.
See settings below.
children.name: BOOTLOADER_APP_TEST
children.title: GPIO triggers boot from test app partition

children.help:
The GPIO must be held low continuously for this period of time after reset
before a factory reset or test partition boot (as applicable) is performed.
children.name: BOOTLOADER_HOLD_TIME_GPIO
children.title: Hold time of GPIO for reset/test mode (seconds)

children.help:
On first boot, the bootloader will generate a key which is not readable externally or by software. A digest is generated from the bootloader image itself. This digest will be verified on each subsequent boot.

Enabling this option means that the bootloader cannot be changed after the first time it is booted.
children.name: SECURE_BOOTLOADER_ONE_TIME_FLASH
children.title: One-time flash

children.help:
Generate a reusable secure bootloader key, derived (via SHA-256) from the secure boot signing key.

This allows the secure bootloader to be re-flashed by anyone with access to the secure boot signing key.

This option is less secure than one-time flash, because a leak of the digest key from one device allows reflashing of any device that uses it.
children.name: SECURE_BOOTLOADER_REFLASHABLE
children.title: Reflashable

children.help:
Path to the key file used to sign partition tables and app images for secure boot. Once secure boot is enabled, bootloader will only boot if partition table and app image are signed.

Key file is an ECDSA private key (NIST256p curve) in PEM format.

Path is evaluated relative to the project directory.

You can generate a new signing key by running the following command:
espsecure.py generate_signing_key secure_boot_signing_key.pem

See docs/security/secure-boot.rst for details.
children.name: SECURE_BOOT_SIGNING_KEY
children.title: Secure boot private signing key

children.help:
Once secure boot is enabled, bootloader will only boot if partition table and app image are signed.

If enabled, these binary files are signed as part of the build process. The file named in "Secure boot private signing key" will be used to sign the image.

If disabled, unsigned app/partition data will be built. They must be signed manually using espsecure.py (for example, on a remote signing server.)
children.name: SECURE_BOOT_BUILD_SIGNED_BINARIES
children.title: Sign binaries during build

children.help:
Path to a public key file used to verify signed images. This key is compiled into the bootloader,
and may also be used to verify signatures on OTA images after download.

Key file is in raw binary format, and can be extracted from a
PEM formatted private key using the espsecure.py
extract_public_key command.

Refer to https://esp-idf.readthedocs.io/en/latest/security/secure-boot.html before enabling.
children.name: SECURE_BOOT_VERIFICATION_KEY
children.title: Secure boot public signature verification key

children.help:
You can disable some of the default protections offered by secure boot, in order to enable testing or a custom combination of security features.

Only enable these options if you are very sure.

Refer to https://esp-idf.readthedocs.io/en/latest/security/secure-boot.html before enabling.
children.name: SECURE_BOOT_INSECURE
children.title: Allow potentially insecure options

children.help:
Build a bootloader which enables secure boot on first boot.

Once enabled, secure boot will not boot a modified bootloader. The bootloader will only load a partition table or boot an app if the data has a verified digital signature. There are implications for reflashing updated apps once secure boot is enabled.

When enabling secure boot, JTAG and ROM BASIC Interpreter are permanently disabled by default.

Refer to https://esp-idf.readthedocs.io/en/latest/security/secure-boot.html before enabling.
children.name: SECURE_BOOT_ENABLED
children.title: Enable secure boot in bootloader (READ DOCS FIRST)

children.help:
You can disable some of the default protections offered by flash encryption, in order to enable testing or a custom combination of security features.

Only enable these options if you are very sure.

Refer to docs/security/secure-boot.rst and docs/security/flash-encryption.rst for details.
children.name: FLASH_ENCRYPTION_INSECURE
children.title: Allow potentially insecure options

children.help:
If this option is set, flash contents will be encrypted by the bootloader on first boot.

Note: After first boot, the system will be permanently encrypted. Re-flashing an encrypted
system is complicated and not always possible.

Read https://esp-idf.readthedocs.io/en/latest/security/flash-encryption.html before enabling.
children.name: FLASH_ENCRYPTION_ENABLED
children.title: Enable flash encryption on boot (READ DOCS FIRST)

children.help:
By default, the BASIC ROM Console starts on reset if no valid bootloader is
read from the flash.

When either flash encryption or secure boot are enabled, the default is to
disable this BASIC fallback mode permanently via efuse.

If this option is set, this efuse is not burned and the BASIC ROM Console may
remain accessible.  Only set this option in testing environments.
children.name: SECURE_BOOT_ALLOW_ROM_BASIC
children.title: Leave ROM BASIC Interpreter available on reset

children.help:
If not set (default), the bootloader will permanently disable JTAG (across entire chip) on first boot when either secure boot or flash encryption is enabled.

Setting this option leaves JTAG on for debugging, which negates all protections of flash encryption and some of the protections of secure boot.

Only set this option in testing environments.
children.name: SECURE_BOOT_ALLOW_JTAG
children.title: Allow JTAG Debugging

children.help:
If not set (default), the bootloader will permanently disable UART bootloader encryption access on first boot. If set, the UART bootloader will still be able to access hardware encryption.

It is recommended to only set this option in testing environments.
children.name: FLASH_ENCRYPTION_UART_BOOTLOADER_ALLOW_ENCRYPT
children.title: Leave UART bootloader encryption enabled

children.help:
If not set (default), the bootloader will permanently disable UART bootloader decryption access on first boot. If set, the UART bootloader will still be able to access hardware decryption.

Only set this option in testing environments. Setting this option allows complete bypass of flash encryption.
children.name: FLASH_ENCRYPTION_UART_BOOTLOADER_ALLOW_DECRYPT
children.title: Leave UART bootloader decryption enabled

children.help:
If not set (default), the bootloader will permanently disable UART bootloader flash cache access on first boot. If set, the UART bootloader will still be able to access the flash cache.

Only set this option in testing environments.
children.name: FLASH_ENCRYPTION_UART_BOOTLOADER_ALLOW_CACHE
children.title: Leave UART bootloader flash cache enabled

children.help:
If this option is set, all permanent secure boot changes (via Efuse) are disabled.

Log output will state changes which would be applied, but they will not be.

This option is for testing purposes only - it completely disables secure boot protection.
children.name: SECURE_BOOT_TEST_MODE
children.title: Secure boot test mode: don't permanently set any efuses

children.help:
The serial port that's connected to the ESP chip. This can be overridden by setting the ESPPORT
environment variable.

This value is ignored when using the CMake-based build system or idf.py.
children.name: ESPTOOLPY_PORT
children.title: Default serial port

children.help:
Default baud rate to use while communicating with the ESP chip. Can be overridden by
setting the ESPBAUD variable.

This value is ignored when using the CMake-based build system or idf.py.
children.name: ESPTOOLPY_BAUD
children.title: Default baud rate

children.help:
The flasher tool can send data compressed using zlib, letting the ROM on the ESP chip
decompress it on the fly before flashing it. For most payloads, this should result in a
speed increase.
children.name: ESPTOOLPY_COMPRESSED
children.title: Use compressed upload

children.help:
Mode the flash chip is flashed in, as well as the default mode for the
binary to run in.
children.name: FLASHMODE
children.title: Flash SPI mode

children.help: The SPI flash frequency to be used.
children.name: ESPTOOLPY_FLASHFREQ
children.title: Flash SPI speed

children.help: SPI flash size, in megabytes
children.name: ESPTOOLPY_FLASHSIZE
children.title: Flash size

children.help:
If this option is set, 'make flash' targets will automatically detect
the flash size and update the bootloader image when flashing.
children.name: ESPTOOLPY_FLASHSIZE_DETECT
children.title: Detect flash size when flashing bootloader

children.help:
Configure whether esptool.py should reset the ESP32 before flashing.

Automatic resetting depends on the RTS & DTR signals being
wired from the serial port to the ESP32. Most USB development
boards do this internally.
children.name: ESPTOOLPY_BEFORE
children.title: Before flashing

children.help:
Configure whether esptool.py should reset the ESP32 after flashing.

Automatic resetting depends on the RTS & DTR signals being
wired from the serial port to the ESP32. Most USB development
boards do this internally.
children.name: ESPTOOLPY_AFTER
children.title: After flashing

children.help:
Baud rate to use when running 'make monitor' to view serial output
from a running chip.

Can override by setting the MONITORBAUD environment variable.
children.name: MONITOR_BAUD
children.title: 'make monitor' baud rate

children.help:
The partition table to flash to the ESP32. The partition table
determines where apps, data and other resources are expected to
be found.

The predefined partition table CSV descriptions can be found
in the components/partition_table directory. Otherwise it's
possible to create a new custom partition CSV for your application.
children.name: PARTITION_TABLE_TYPE
children.title: Partition Table

children.help:
Name of the custom partition CSV filename. This path is evaluated
relative to the project root directory.
children.name: PARTITION_TABLE_CUSTOM_FILENAME
children.title: Custom partition CSV file

children.help:
If using a custom partition table, specify the offset in the flash
where 'make flash' should write the built app.
children.name: PARTITION_TABLE_CUSTOM_APP_BIN_OFFSET
children.title: Factory app partition offset

children.help:
If using a custom partition table, specify the offset in the flash
where 'make flash' should write the initial PHY data file.
children.name: PARTITION_TABLE_CUSTOM_PHY_DATA_OFFSET
children.title: PHY data partition offset

children.help:
Generate an MD5 checksum for the partition table for protecting the
integrity of the table. The generation should be turned off for legacy
bootloaders which cannot recognize the MD5 checksum in the partition
table.
children.name: PARTITION_TABLE_MD5
children.title: Generate an MD5 checksum for the partition table

children.help:
This option sets compiler optimization level (gcc -O argument).

- for "Release" setting, -Os flag is added to CFLAGS.
- for "Debug" setting, -Og flag is added to CFLAGS.

"Release" with -Os produces smaller & faster compiled code but it
may be harder to correlated code addresses to source files when debugging.

To add custom optimization settings, set CFLAGS and/or CPPFLAGS
in project makefile, before including $(IDF_PATH)/make/project.mk. Note that
custom optimization levels may be unsupported.
children.name: OPTIMIZATION_COMPILER
children.title: Optimization Level

children.help: Enable assertions. Assertion content and line number will be printed on failure.
children.name: OPTIMIZATION_ASSERTIONS_ENABLED
children.title: Enabled

children.help:
Enable silent assertions. Failed assertions will abort(), user needs to
use the aborting address to find the line number with the failed assertion.
children.name: OPTIMIZATION_ASSERTIONS_SILENT
children.title: Silent (saves code size)

children.help: If assertions are disabled, -DNDEBUG is added to CPPFLAGS.
children.name: OPTIMIZATION_ASSERTIONS_DISABLED
children.title: Disabled (sets -DNDEBUG)

children.help:
Assertions can be:
- Enabled. Failure will print verbose assertion details. This is the default.

- Set to "silent" to save code size (failed assertions will abort() but user
  needs to use the aborting address to find the line number with the failed assertion.)

- Disabled entirely (not recommended for most configurations.) -DNDEBUG is added
  to CPPFLAGS in this case.
children.name: OPTIMIZATION_ASSERTION_LEVEL
children.title: Assertion level

children.help:
Size (in bytes) of the emergency memory pool for C++ exceptions. This pool will be used to allocate
memory for thrown exceptions when there is not enough memory on the heap.
children.name: CXX_EXCEPTIONS_EMG_POOL_SIZE
children.title: Emergency Pool Size

children.help:
Enabling this option compiles all IDF C++ files with exception support enabled.

Disabling this option disables C++ exception support in all compiled files, and any libstdc++ code which throws
an exception will abort instead.

Enabling this option currently adds an additional ~500 bytes of heap overhead
when an exception is thrown in user code for the first time.
children.name: CXX_EXCEPTIONS
children.title: Enable C++ exceptions

children.help:
Stack smashing protection mode. Emit extra code to check for buffer overflows, such as stack
smashing attacks. This is done by adding a guard variable to functions with vulnerable objects.
The guards are initialized when a function is entered and then checked when the function exits.
If a guard check fails, program is halted. Protection has the following modes:

  - In NORMAL mode (GCC flag: -fstack-protector) only functions that call
    alloca, and functions with buffers larger than 8 bytes are protected.
  - STRONG mode (GCC flag: -fstack-protector-strong) is like NORMAL, but
    includes additional functions to be protected -- those that have
    local array definitions, or have references to local frame addresses.
  - In OVERALL mode (GCC flag: -fstack-protector-all) all functions are
    protected.

Modes have the following impact on code performance and coverage:
  - performance: NORMAL > STRONG > OVERALL
  - coverage: NORMAL < STRONG < OVERALL
children.name: STACK_CHECK_MODE
children.title: Stack smashing protection mode

children.help: Stack smashing protection.
children.name: STACK_CHECK

children.help:
Adds -Wwrite-strings flag for the C/C++ compilers.

For C, this gives string constants the type "const char[]" so that
copying the address of one into a non-"const" "char *" pointer
produces a warning. This warning helps to find at compile time code
that tries to write into a string constant.

For C++, this warns about the deprecated conversion from string
literals to "char *".
children.name: WARN_WRITE_STRINGS
children.title: Enable -Wwrite-strings warning flag

children.help:
If this option is enabled, if SPI flash write verification fails then a log error line
will be written with the address, expected & actual values. This can be useful when
debugging hardware SPI flash problems.
children.name: SPI_FLASH_LOG_FAILED_WRITE
children.title: Log errors if verification fails

children.help:
If this option is enabled, any SPI flash write which tries to set zero bits in the flash to
ones will log a warning. Such writes will not result in the requested data appearing identically
in flash once written, as SPI NOR flash can only set bits to one when an entire sector is erased.
After erasing, individual bits can only be written from one to zero.

Note that some software (such as SPIFFS) which is aware of SPI NOR flash may write one bits as an
optimisation, relying on the data in flash becoming a bitwise AND of the new data and any existing data.
Such software will log spurious warnings if this option is enabled.
children.name: SPI_FLASH_WARN_SETTING_ZERO_TO_ONE
children.title: Log warning if writing zero bits to ones

children.help:
If this option is enabled, any time SPI flash is written then the data will be read
back and verified. This can catch hardware problems with SPI flash, or flash which
was not erased before verification.
children.name: SPI_FLASH_VERIFY_WRITE
children.title: Verify SPI flash writes

children.help:
This option enables the following APIs:

- spi_flash_reset_counters
- spi_flash_dump_counters
- spi_flash_get_counters

These APIs may be used to collect performance data for spi_flash APIs
and to help understand behaviour of libraries which use SPI flash.
children.name: SPI_FLASH_ENABLE_COUNTERS
children.title: Enable operation counters

children.help:
Enable this flag to use patched versions of SPI flash ROM driver functions.
This option is needed to write to flash on ESP32-D2WD, and any configuration
where external SPI flash is connected to non-default pins.
children.name: SPI_FLASH_ROM_DRIVER_PATCH
children.title: Enable SPI flash ROM driver patched functions

children.help:
SPI flash APIs can optionally abort or return a failure code
if erasing or writing addresses that fall at the beginning
of flash (covering the bootloader and partition table) or that
overlap the app partition that contains the running app.

It is not recommended to ever write to these regions from an IDF app,
and this check prevents logic errors or corrupted firmware memory from
damaging these regions.

Note that this feature *does not* check calls to the esp_rom_xxx SPI flash
ROM functions. These functions should not be called directly from IDF
applications.
children.name: SPI_FLASH_WRITING_DANGEROUS_REGIONS
children.title: Writing to dangerous flash regions

children.help:
Maximum TLS message length (in bytes) supported by mbedTLS.

16384 is the default and this value is required to comply
fully with TLS standards.

However you can set a lower value in order to save RAM. This
is safe if the other end of the connection supports Maximum
Fragment Length Negotiation Extension (max_fragment_length,
see RFC6066) or you know for certain that it will never send a
message longer than a certain number of bytes.

If the value is set too low, symptoms are a failed TLS
handshake or a return value of MBEDTLS_ERR_SSL_INVALID_RECORD
(-0x7200).
children.name: MBEDTLS_SSL_MAX_CONTENT_LEN
children.title: TLS maximum message content length

children.help:
Enable mbedTLS debugging functions at compile time.

If this option is enabled, you can include
    "mbedtls/esp_debug.h" and call mbedtls_esp_enable_debug_log()
    at runtime in order to enable mbedTLS debug output via the ESP
    log mechanism.
children.name: MBEDTLS_DEBUG
children.title: Enable mbedTLS debugging

children.help:
Enable hardware accelerated AES encryption & decryption.

Note that if the ESP32 CPU is running at 240MHz, hardware AES does not
offer any speed boost over software AES.
children.name: MBEDTLS_HARDWARE_AES
children.title: Enable hardware AES acceleration

children.help:
Use an interrupt to coordinate MPI operations.

This allows other code to run on the CPU while an MPI operation is pending.
Otherwise the CPU busy-waits.
children.name: MBEDTLS_MPI_USE_INTERRUPT
children.title: Use interrupt for MPI operations

children.help:
Enable hardware accelerated multiple precision integer operations.

Hardware accelerated multiplication, modulo multiplication,
and modular exponentiation for up to 4096 bit results.

These operations are used by RSA.
children.name: MBEDTLS_HARDWARE_MPI
children.title: Enable hardware MPI (bignum) acceleration

children.help:
Enable hardware accelerated SHA1, SHA256, SHA384 & SHA512 in mbedTLS.

Due to a hardware limitation, hardware acceleration is only
guaranteed if SHA digests are calculated one at a time. If more
than one SHA digest is calculated at the same time, one will
be calculated fully in hardware and the rest will be calculated
(at least partially calculated) in software. This happens automatically.

SHA hardware acceleration is faster than software in some situations but
slower in others. You should benchmark to find the best setting for you.
children.name: MBEDTLS_HARDWARE_SHA
children.title: Enable hardware SHA acceleration

children.help:
System has time.h and time(), gmtime() and the clock is correct.
The time needs to be correct (not necesarily very accurate, but at least
the date should be correct). This is used to verify the validity period of
X.509 certificates.

It is suggested that you should get the real time by "SNTP".
children.name: MBEDTLS_HAVE_TIME_DATE
children.title: Enable mbedtls time data

children.help:
System has time.h and time().
The time does not need to be correct, only time differences are used,
children.name: MBEDTLS_HAVE_TIME
children.title: Enable mbedtls time

children.help:
mbedTLS can be compiled with protocol support for the TLS
server, TLS client, or both server and client.

Reducing the number of TLS roles supported saves code size.
children.name: MBEDTLS_TLS_MODE
children.title: TLS Protocol Role

children.help: Enable to support symmetric key PSK (pre-shared-key) TLS key exchange modes.
children.name: MBEDTLS_KEY_EXCHANGE_PSK
children.title: Enable PSK based ciphersuite modes

children.help: Enable to support Diffie-Hellman PSK (pre-shared-key) TLS authentication modes.
children.name: MBEDTLS_KEY_EXCHANGE_DHE_PSK
children.title: Enable DHE-PSK based ciphersuite modes

children.help: Enable to support Elliptic-Curve-Diffie-Hellman PSK (pre-shared-key) TLS authentication modes.
children.name: MBEDTLS_KEY_EXCHANGE_ECDHE_PSK
children.title: Enable ECDHE-PSK based ciphersuite modes

children.help: Enable to support RSA PSK (pre-shared-key) TLS authentication modes.
children.name: MBEDTLS_KEY_EXCHANGE_RSA_PSK
children.title: Enable RSA-PSK based ciphersuite modes

children.help:
Enable to show configuration for different types of pre-shared-key TLS authentatication methods.

Leaving this options disabled will save code size if they are not used.
children.name: MBEDTLS_PSK_MODES
children.title: Enable pre-shared-key ciphersuites

children.help: Enable to support ciphersuites with prefix TLS-RSA-WITH-
children.name: MBEDTLS_KEY_EXCHANGE_RSA
children.title: Enable RSA-only based ciphersuite modes

children.help: Enable to support ciphersuites with prefix TLS-DHE-RSA-WITH-
children.name: MBEDTLS_KEY_EXCHANGE_DHE_RSA
children.title: Enable DHE-RSA based ciphersuite modes

children.help: Enable to support ciphersuites with prefix TLS-ECDHE-RSA-WITH-
children.name: MBEDTLS_KEY_EXCHANGE_ECDHE_RSA
children.title: Enable ECDHE-RSA based ciphersuite modes

children.help: Enable to support ciphersuites with prefix TLS-ECDHE-RSA-WITH-
children.name: MBEDTLS_KEY_EXCHANGE_ECDHE_ECDSA
children.title: Enable ECDHE-ECDSA based ciphersuite modes

children.help: Enable to support ciphersuites with prefix TLS-ECDHE-RSA-WITH-
children.name: MBEDTLS_KEY_EXCHANGE_ECDH_ECDSA
children.title: Enable ECDH-ECDSA based ciphersuite modes

children.help: Enable to support ciphersuites with prefix TLS-ECDHE-RSA-WITH-
children.name: MBEDTLS_KEY_EXCHANGE_ECDH_RSA
children.title: Enable ECDH-RSA based ciphersuite modes

children.help:
Enable to show Elliptic Curve based ciphersuite mode options.

Disabling all Elliptic Curve ciphersuites saves code size and
can give slightly faster TLS handshakes, provided the server supports
RSA-only ciphersuite modes.
children.name: MBEDTLS_KEY_EXCHANGE_ELLIPTIC_CURVE
children.title: Support Elliptic Curve based ciphersuites

children.help:
The two main uses of renegotiation are (1) refresh keys on long-lived
connections and (2) client authentication after the initial handshake.
If you don't need renegotiation, disabling it will save code size and
reduce the possibility of abuse/vulnerability.
children.name: MBEDTLS_SSL_RENEGOTIATION
children.title: Support TLS renegotiation

children.help:
Support the legacy SSL 3.0 protocol. Most servers will speak a newer
TLS protocol these days.
children.name: MBEDTLS_SSL_PROTO_SSL3
children.title: Legacy SSL 3.0 support

children.help:
Requires TLS 1.1 to be enabled for DTLS 1.0
Requires TLS 1.2 to be enabled for DTLS 1.2
children.name: MBEDTLS_SSL_PROTO_DTLS
children.title: Support DTLS protocol (all versions)

children.help: Disabling this option will save some code size if it is not needed.
children.name: MBEDTLS_SSL_ALPN
children.title: Support ALPN (Application Layer Protocol Negotiation)

children.help:
Support RFC 5077 session tickets. See mbedTLS documentation for more details.

Disabling this option will save some code size.
children.name: MBEDTLS_SSL_SESSION_TICKETS
children.title: TLS: Support RFC 5077 SSL session tickets

children.help:
Enables the DES block cipher to support 3DES-based TLS ciphersuites.

3DES is vulnerable to the Sweet32 attack and should only be enabled
if absolutely necessary.
children.name: MBEDTLS_DES_C
children.title: DES block cipher (legacy, insecure)

children.help:
ARCFOUR (RC4) stream cipher can be disabled entirely, enabled but not
added to default ciphersuites, or enabled completely.

Please consider the security implications before enabling RC4.
children.name: MBEDTLS_RC4_MODE
children.title: RC4 Stream Cipher (legacy, insecure)

children.help:
Enables the Blowfish block cipher (not used for TLS sessions.)

The Blowfish cipher is not used for mbedTLS TLS sessions but can be
used for other purposes. Read up on the limitations of Blowfish (including
Sweet32) before enabling.
children.name: MBEDTLS_BLOWFISH_C
children.title: Blowfish block cipher (read help)

children.help: Enables the XTEA block cipher.
children.name: MBEDTLS_XTEA_C
children.title: XTEA block cipher

children.help:
Enable Counter with CBC-MAC (CCM) modes for AES and/or Camellia ciphers.

Disabling this option saves some code size.
children.name: MBEDTLS_CCM_C
children.title: CCM (Counter with CBC-MAC) block cipher modes

children.help:
Enable Galois/Counter Mode for AES and/or Camellia ciphers.

This option is generally faster than CCM.
children.name: MBEDTLS_GCM_C
children.title: GCM (Galois/Counter) block cipher modes

children.help: Enable the RIPEMD-160 hash algorithm.
children.name: MBEDTLS_RIPEMD160_C
children.title: Enable RIPEMD-160 hash algorithm

children.help:
Enable decoding/parsing of PEM formatted certificates.

If your certificates are all in the simpler DER format, disabling
this option will save some code size.
children.name: MBEDTLS_PEM_PARSE_C
children.title: Read & Parse PEM formatted certificates

children.help:
Enable writing of PEM formatted certificates.

If writing certificate data only in DER format, disabling this
option will save some code size.
children.name: MBEDTLS_PEM_WRITE_C
children.title: Write PEM formatted certificates

children.help: Support for parsing X.509 Certifificate Revocation Lists.
children.name: MBEDTLS_X509_CRL_PARSE_C
children.title: X.509 CRL parsing

children.help: Support for parsing X.509 Certifificate Signing Requests
children.name: MBEDTLS_X509_CSR_PARSE_C
children.title: X.509 CSR parsing

children.help: Enable ECDSA. Needed to use ECDSA-xxx TLS ciphersuites.
children.name: MBEDTLS_ECDSA_C
children.title: Elliptic Curve DSA

children.help: Enable ECDH. Needed to use ECDHE-xxx TLS ciphersuites.
children.name: MBEDTLS_ECDH_C
children.title: Elliptic Curve Diffie-Hellman (ECDH)

children.help: Enable support for SECP192R1 Elliptic Curve.
children.name: MBEDTLS_ECP_DP_SECP192R1_ENABLED
children.title: Enable SECP192R1 curve

children.help: Enable support for SECP224R1 Elliptic Curve.
children.name: MBEDTLS_ECP_DP_SECP224R1_ENABLED
children.title: Enable SECP224R1 curve

children.help: Enable support for SECP256R1 Elliptic Curve.
children.name: MBEDTLS_ECP_DP_SECP256R1_ENABLED
children.title: Enable SECP256R1 curve

children.help: Enable support for SECP384R1 Elliptic Curve.
children.name: MBEDTLS_ECP_DP_SECP384R1_ENABLED
children.title: Enable SECP384R1 curve

children.help: Enable support for SECP521R1 Elliptic Curve.
children.name: MBEDTLS_ECP_DP_SECP521R1_ENABLED
children.title: Enable SECP521R1 curve

children.help: Enable support for SECP192K1 Elliptic Curve.
children.name: MBEDTLS_ECP_DP_SECP192K1_ENABLED
children.title: Enable SECP192K1 curve

children.help: Enable support for SECP224K1 Elliptic Curve.
children.name: MBEDTLS_ECP_DP_SECP224K1_ENABLED
children.title: Enable SECP224K1 curve

children.help: Enable support for SECP256K1 Elliptic Curve.
children.name: MBEDTLS_ECP_DP_SECP256K1_ENABLED
children.title: Enable SECP256K1 curve

children.help: support for DP Elliptic Curve.
children.name: MBEDTLS_ECP_DP_BP256R1_ENABLED
children.title: Enable BP256R1 curve

children.help: support for DP Elliptic Curve.
children.name: MBEDTLS_ECP_DP_BP384R1_ENABLED
children.title: Enable BP384R1 curve

children.help: support for DP Elliptic Curve.
children.name: MBEDTLS_ECP_DP_BP512R1_ENABLED
children.title: Enable BP512R1 curve

children.help: Enable support for CURVE25519 Elliptic Curve.
children.name: MBEDTLS_ECP_DP_CURVE25519_ENABLED
children.title: Enable CURVE25519 curve

children.help:
NIST 'modulo p' optimisations increase Elliptic Curve operation performance.

Disabling this option saves some code size.
children.name: MBEDTLS_ECP_NIST_OPTIM
children.title: NIST 'modulo p' optimisations

children.help:
If this feature is enabled, all traffic from layer2(WIFI Driver) will be
copied to a new buffer before sending it to layer3(LWIP stack), freeing
the layer2 buffer.
Please be notified that the total layer2 receiving buffer is fixed and
ESP32 currently supports 25 layer2 receiving buffer, when layer2 buffer
runs out of memory, then the incoming packets will be dropped in hardware.
The layer3 buffer is allocated from the heap, so the total layer3 receiving
buffer depends on the available heap size, when heap runs out of memory,
no copy will be sent to layer3 and packet will be dropped in layer2.
Please make sure you fully understand the impact of this feature before
enabling it.
children.name: L2_TO_L3_COPY
children.title: Enable copy between Layer2 and Layer3 packets

children.help:
If this feature is enabled, some functions relating to RX/TX in LWIP will be
put into IRAM, it can improve UDP/TCP throughput by >10% for single core mode,
it doesn't help too much for dual core mode. On the other hand, it needs about
10KB IRAM for these optimizations.

If this feature is disabled, all lwip functions will be put into FLASH.
children.name: LWIP_IRAM_OPTIMIZATION
children.title: Enable LWIP IRAM optimization

children.help:
Sockets take up a certain amount of memory, and allowing fewer
sockets to be open at the same time conserves memory. Specify
the maximum amount of sockets here. The valid value is from 1
to 16.
children.name: LWIP_MAX_SOCKETS
children.title: Max number of open sockets

children.help:
The virtual filesystem layer of select() redirects sockets to
lwip_select() and non-socket file descriptors to their respective driver
implementations. If this option is enabled then all calls of select()
will be redirected to lwip_select(), therefore, select can be used
for sockets only.
children.name: USE_ONLY_LWIP_SELECT
children.title: Support LWIP socket select() only

children.help:
Enabling this option means that any incoming broadcast or multicast
packet will be copied to all of the local sockets that it matches
(may be more than one if SO_REUSEADDR is set on the socket.)

This increases memory overhead as the packets need to be copied,
however they are only copied per matching socket. You can safely
disable it if you don't plan to receive broadcast or multicast
traffic on more than one socket at a time.
children.name: LWIP_SO_REUSE_RXTOALL
children.title: SO_REUSEADDR copies broadcast/multicast to all matches

children.help:
Enabling this option allows binding to a port which remains in
TIME_WAIT.
children.name: LWIP_SO_REUSE
children.title: Enable SO_REUSEADDR option

children.help: Enabling this option allows checking for available data on a netconn.
children.name: LWIP_SO_RCVBUF
children.title: Enable SO_RCVBUF option

children.help:
Set maximum number of NTP servers used by LwIP SNTP module.
First argument of sntp_setserver/sntp_setservername functions
is limited to this value.
children.name: LWIP_DHCP_MAX_NTP_SERVERS
children.title: Maximum number of NTP servers

children.help:
Enabling this option allows fragmenting outgoing IP packets if their size
exceeds MTU.
children.name: LWIP_IP_FRAG
children.title: Enable fragment outgoing IP packets

children.help: Enabling this option allows reassemblying incoming fragmented IP packets.
children.name: LWIP_IP_REASSEMBLY
children.title: Enable reassembly incoming fragmented IP packets

children.help: Enabling this option allows LWIP statistics
children.name: LWIP_STATS
children.title: Enable LWIP statistics

children.help:
Enabling this option allows ARP table to be updated.

If this option is enabled, the incoming IP packets cause the ARP table to be
updated with the source MAC and IP addresses supplied in the packet.
You may want to disable this if you do not trust LAN peers to have the
correct addresses, or as a limited approach to attempt to handle
spoofing. If disabled, lwIP will need to make a new ARP request if
the peer is not already in the ARP table, adding a little latency.
The peer *is* in the ARP table if it requested our address before.
Also notice that this slows down input processing of every IP packet!
children.name: LWIP_ETHARP_TRUST_IP_MAC
children.title: Enable LWIP ARP trust

children.help:
Set TCPIP task receive mail box size. Generally bigger value means higher throughput
but more memory. The value should be bigger than UDP/TCP mail box size.
children.name: TCPIP_RECVMBOX_SIZE
children.title: TCPIP task receive mail box size

children.help:
Enabling this option performs a check (via ARP request) if the offered IP address
is not already in use by another host on the network.
children.name: LWIP_DHCP_DOES_ARP_CHECK
children.title: DHCP: Perform ARP check on any offered address

children.help:
The DHCP server is calculating lease time multiplying the sent
and received times by this number of seconds per unit.
The default is 60, that equals one minute.
children.name: LWIP_DHCPS_LEASE_UNIT
children.title: Multiplier for lease time, in seconds

children.help:
The maximum number of DHCP clients that are connected to the server.
After this number is exceeded, DHCP server removes of the oldest device
from it's address pool, without notification.
children.name: LWIP_DHCPS_MAX_STATION_NUM
children.title: Maximum number of stations

children.help:
DHCP client will send this many probes before self-assigning a
link local address.

From LWIP help: "This can be set as low as 1 to get an AutoIP
address very quickly, but you should be prepared to handle a
changing IP address when DHCP overrides AutoIP." (In the case of
ESP-IDF, this means multiple SYSTEM_EVENT_STA_GOT_IP events.)
children.name: LWIP_AUTOIP_TRIES
children.title: DHCP Probes before self-assigning IPv4 LL address

children.help:
If the AUTOIP functionality detects this many IP conflicts while
self-assigning an address, it will go into a rate limited mode.
children.name: LWIP_AUTOIP_MAX_CONFLICTS
children.title: Max IP conflicts before rate limiting

children.help:
If rate limiting self-assignment requests, wait this long between
each request.
children.name: LWIP_AUTOIP_RATE_LIMIT_INTERVAL
children.title: Rate limited interval (seconds)

children.help:
Enabling this option allows the device to self-assign an address
in the 169.256/16 range if none is assigned statically or via DHCP.

See RFC 3927.
children.name: LWIP_AUTOIP
children.title: Enable IPV4 Link-Local Addressing (AUTOIP)

children.help:
Configure the maximum number of packets which can be queued for
loopback on a given interface. Reducing this number may cause packets
to be dropped, but will avoid filling memory with queued packet data.
children.name: LWIP_LOOPBACK_MAX_PBUFS
children.title: Max queued loopback packets per interface

children.help:
Enabling this option means that if a packet is sent with a destination
address equal to the interface's own IP address, it will "loop back" and
be received by this interface.
children.name: LWIP_NETIF_LOOPBACK
children.title: Support per-interface loopback

children.help:
The maximum number of simultaneously active TCP
connections. The practical maximum limit is
determined by available heap memory at runtime.

Changing this value by itself does not substantially
change the memory usage of LWIP, except for preventing
new TCP connections after the limit is reached.
children.name: LWIP_MAX_ACTIVE_TCP
children.title: Maximum active TCP Connections

children.help:
The maximum number of simultaneously listening TCP
connections. The practical maximum limit is
determined by available heap memory at runtime.

Changing this value by itself does not substantially
change the memory usage of LWIP, except for preventing
new listening TCP connections after the limit is reached.
children.name: LWIP_MAX_LISTENING_TCP
children.title: Maximum listening TCP Connections

children.help: Set maximum number of retransmissions of data segments.
children.name: TCP_MAXRTX
children.title: Maximum number of retransmissions of data segments

children.help: Set maximum number of retransmissions of SYN segments.
children.name: TCP_SYNMAXRTX
children.title: Maximum number of retransmissions of SYN segments

children.help:
Set maximum segment size for TCP transmission.

Can be set lower to save RAM, the default value 1436 will give best throughput.
children.name: TCP_MSS
children.title: Maximum Segment Size (MSS)

children.help: Set maximum segment lifetime in in milliseconds.
children.name: TCP_MSL
children.title: Maximum segment lifetime (MSL)

children.help:
Set default send buffer size for new TCP sockets.

Per-socket send buffer size can be changed at runtime
with lwip_setsockopt(s, TCP_SNDBUF, ...).

This value must be at least 2x the MSS size, and the default
is 4x the default MSS size.

Setting a smaller default SNDBUF size can save some RAM, but
will decrease performance.
children.name: TCP_SND_BUF_DEFAULT
children.title: Default send buffer size

children.help:
Set default TCP receive window size for new TCP sockets.

Per-socket receive window size can be changed at runtime
with lwip_setsockopt(s, TCP_WINDOW, ...).

Setting a smaller default receive window size can save some RAM,
but will significantly decrease performance.
children.name: TCP_WND_DEFAULT
children.title: Default receive window size

children.help:
Set TCP receive mail box size. Generally bigger value means higher throughput
but more memory. The recommended value is: TCP_WND_DEFAULT/TCP_MSS + 2, e.g. if
TCP_WND_DEFAULT=14360, TCP_MSS=1436, then the recommended receive mail box size is
(14360/1436 + 2) = 12.

TCP receive mail box is a per socket mail box, when the application receives packets
from TCP socket, LWIP core firstly posts the packets to TCP receive mail box and the
application then fetches the packets from mail box. It means LWIP can caches maximum
TCP_RECCVMBOX_SIZE packets for each TCP socket, so the maximum possible cached TCP packets
for all TCP sockets is TCP_RECCVMBOX_SIZE multiples the maximum TCP socket number. In other
words, the bigger TCP_RECVMBOX_SIZE means more memory.
On the other hand, if the receiv mail box is too small, the mail box may be full. If the
mail box is full, the LWIP drops the packets. So generally we need to make sure the TCP
receive mail box is big enough to avoid packet drop between LWIP core and application.
children.name: TCP_RECVMBOX_SIZE
children.title: Default TCP receive mail box size

children.help:
Queue incoming out-of-order segments for later use.

Disable this option to save some RAM during TCP sessions, at the expense
of increased retransmissions if segments arrive out of order.
children.name: TCP_QUEUE_OOSEQ
children.title: Queue incoming out-of-order segments

children.help:
Allows enabling "oversize" allocation of TCP transmission pbufs ahead of time,
which can reduce the length of pbuf chains used for transmission.

This will not make a difference to sockets where Nagle's algorithm
is disabled.

Default value of MSS is fine for most applications, 25% MSS may save
some RAM when only transmitting small amounts of data. Disabled will
have worst performance and fragmentation characteristics, but uses
least RAM overall.
children.name: TCP_OVERSIZE
children.title: Pre-allocate transmit PBUF size

children.help:
The maximum number of active UDP "connections" (ie
UDP sockets sending/receiving data).
The practical maximum limit is determined by available
heap memory at runtime.
children.name: LWIP_MAX_UDP_PCBS
children.title: Maximum active UDP control blocks

children.help:
Set UDP receive mail box size. The recommended value is 6.

UDP receive mail box is a per socket mail box, when the application receives packets
from UDP socket, LWIP core firstly posts the packets to UDP receive mail box and the
application then fetches the packets from mail box. It means LWIP can caches maximum
UDP_RECCVMBOX_SIZE packets for each UDP socket, so the maximum possible cached UDP packets
for all UDP sockets is UDP_RECCVMBOX_SIZE multiples the maximum UDP socket number. In other
words, the bigger UDP_RECVMBOX_SIZE means more memory.
On the other hand, if the receiv mail box is too small, the mail box may be full. If the
mail box is full, the LWIP drops the packets. So generally we need to make sure the UDP
receive mail box is big enough to avoid packet drop between LWIP core and application.
children.name: UDP_RECVMBOX_SIZE
children.title: Default UDP receive mail box size

children.help:
Configure TCP/IP task stack size, used by LWIP to process multi-threaded TCP/IP operations.
Setting this stack too small will result in stack overflow crashes.
children.name: TCPIP_TASK_STACK_SIZE
children.title: TCP/IP Task Stack Size

children.help: Enable Password Authentication Protocol (PAP) support
children.name: PPP_PAP_SUPPORT
children.title: Enable PAP support

children.help: Enable Challenge Handshake Authentication Protocol (CHAP) support
children.name: PPP_CHAP_SUPPORT
children.title: Enable CHAP support

children.help: Enable Microsoft version of the Challenge-Handshake Authentication Protocol (MSCHAP) support
children.name: PPP_MSCHAP_SUPPORT
children.title: Enable MSCHAP support

children.help: Enable Microsoft Point-to-Point Encryption (MPPE) support
children.name: PPP_MPPE_SUPPORT
children.title: Enable MPPE support

children.help: Enable PPP debug log output
children.name: PPP_DEBUG_ON
children.title: Enable PPP debug log output

children.help:
Enable PPP stack. Now only PPP over serial is possible.

PPP over serial support is experimental and unsupported.
children.name: PPP_SUPPORT
children.title: Enable PPP support (new/experimental)

children.help:
The maximum number of simultaneously active LWIP
RAW protocol control blocks. The practical maximum
limit is determined by available heap memory at runtime.
children.name: LWIP_MAX_RAW_PCBS
children.title: Maximum LWIP RAW PCBs

children.help:
Select() related functions might produce an unconveniently lot of
debug outputs when one sets the default log level to DEBUG or higher.
It is possible to suppress these debug outputs by enabling this
option.
children.name: SUPPRESS_SELECT_DEBUG_OUTPUT
children.title: Suppress select() related debug outputs

children.help:
Number of DMA receive buffers. Each buffer is 1600 bytes.
Buffers are allocated statically.
Larger number of buffers increases throughput.
If enable flow ctrl, the num must be above 9 .
children.name: DMA_RX_BUF_NUM
children.title: Number of DMA RX buffers

children.help:
Number of DMA transmit buffers. Each buffer is 1600 bytes.
Buffers are allocated statically.
Larger number of buffers increases throughput.
children.name: DMA_TX_BUF_NUM
children.title: Number of DMA TX buffers

children.help:
If this options is selected, a copy of each received buffer will be created when
passing it from the Ethernet MAC (L2) to the IP stack (L3). Otherwise, IP stack
will receive pointers to the DMA buffers used by Ethernet MAC.

When Ethernet MAC doesn't have any unused buffers left, it will drop incomming
packets (flow control may help with this problem, to some extent).

The buffers for the IP stack are allocated from the heap, so the total number of
receive buffers is limited by the available heap size, if this option is selected.

If unsure, choose n.
children.name: EMAC_L2_TO_L3_RX_BUF_MODE
children.title: Enable copy between Layer2 and Layer3

children.help: Ethernet MAC task priority.
children.name: EMAC_TASK_PRIORITY
children.title: EMAC_TASK_PRIORITY

children.help:
The value of 0 indicates the IP lost timer is disabled, otherwise the timer is enabled.

The IP address may be lost because of some reasons, e.g. when the station disconnects
from soft-AP, or when DHCP IP renew fails etc. If the IP lost timer is enabled, it will
be started everytime the IP is lost. Event SYSTEM_EVENT_STA_LOST_IP will be raised if
the timer expires. The IP lost timer is stopped if the station get the IP again before
the timer expires.
children.name: IP_LOST_TIMER_INTERVAL
children.title: IP Address lost timer interval (seconds)

children.help: Select destination for application trace: trace memory or none (to disable).
children.name: ESP32_APPTRACE_DESTINATION
children.title: Data Destination

children.help: Enables/disable application tracing module.
children.name: ESP32_APPTRACE_ENABLE

children.help: Enables/disable application tracing module internal sync lock.
children.name: ESP32_APPTRACE_LOCK_ENABLE

children.help:
Timeout for flushing last trace data to host in case of panic. In ms.
Use -1 to disable timeout and wait forever.
children.name: ESP32_APPTRACE_ONPANIC_HOST_FLUSH_TMO
children.title: Timeout for flushing last trace data to host on panic

children.help:
Threshold for flushing last trace data to host on panic in post-mortem mode.
This is minimal amount of data needed to perform flush. In bytes.
children.name: ESP32_APPTRACE_POSTMORTEM_FLUSH_TRAX_THRESH
children.title: Threshold for flushing last trace data to host on panic

children.help:
Size of the buffer for events in bytes. It is useful for buffering events from
the time critical code (scheduler, ISRs etc). If this parameter is 0 then
events will be discarded when main HW buffer is full.
children.name: ESP32_APPTRACE_PENDING_DATA_SIZE_MAX
children.title: Size of the pending data buffer

children.help:
SystemView needs to use a hardware timer as the source of timestamps
when tracing. This option selects the timer for it.
children.name: SYSVIEW_TS_SOURCE
children.title: Timer to use as timestamp source

children.help: Enables "Trace Buffer Overflow" event.
children.name: SYSVIEW_EVT_OVERFLOW_ENABLE
children.title: Trace Buffer Overflow Event

children.help: Enables "ISR Enter" event.
children.name: SYSVIEW_EVT_ISR_ENTER_ENABLE
children.title: ISR Enter Event

children.help: Enables "ISR Exit" event.
children.name: SYSVIEW_EVT_ISR_EXIT_ENABLE
children.title: ISR Exit Event

children.help: Enables "ISR to Scheduler" event.
children.name: SYSVIEW_EVT_ISR_TO_SCHEDULER_ENABLE
children.title: ISR Exit to Scheduler Event

children.help: Enables "Task Start Execution" event.
children.name: SYSVIEW_EVT_TASK_START_EXEC_ENABLE
children.title: Task Start Execution Event

children.help: Enables "Task Stop Execution" event.
children.name: SYSVIEW_EVT_TASK_STOP_EXEC_ENABLE
children.title: Task Stop Execution Event

children.help: Enables "Task Start Ready State" event.
children.name: SYSVIEW_EVT_TASK_START_READY_ENABLE
children.title: Task Start Ready State Event

children.help: Enables "Task Stop Ready State" event.
children.name: SYSVIEW_EVT_TASK_STOP_READY_ENABLE
children.title: Task Stop Ready State Event

children.help: Enables "Task Create" event.
children.name: SYSVIEW_EVT_TASK_CREATE_ENABLE
children.title: Task Create Event

children.help: Enables "Task Terminate" event.
children.name: SYSVIEW_EVT_TASK_TERMINATE_ENABLE
children.title: Task Terminate Event

children.help: Enables "System Idle" event.
children.name: SYSVIEW_EVT_IDLE_ENABLE
children.title: System Idle Event

children.help: Enables "Timer Enter" event.
children.name: SYSVIEW_EVT_TIMER_ENTER_ENABLE
children.title: Timer Enter Event

children.help: Enables "Timer Exit" event.
children.name: SYSVIEW_EVT_TIMER_EXIT_ENABLE
children.title: Timer Exit Event

children.help: Enables supporrt for SEGGER SystemView tracing functionality.
children.name: SYSVIEW_ENABLE
children.title: SystemView Tracing Enable

children.help: Enables support for GCOV data transfer to host.
children.name: ESP32_GCOV_ENABLE
children.title: GCOV to Host Enable

children.help:
Default endpoint host name to connect to AWS IoT MQTT/S gateway

This is the custom endpoint hostname and is specific to an AWS
IoT account. You can find it by logging into your AWS IoT
Console and clicking the Settings button. The endpoint hostname
is shown under the "Custom Endpoint" heading on this page.

If you need per-device hostnames for different regions or
accounts, you can override the default hostname in your app.
children.name: AWS_IOT_MQTT_HOST
children.title: AWS IoT Endpoint Hostname

children.help:
Default port number to connect to AWS IoT MQTT/S gateway

If you need per-device port numbers for different regions, you can
override the default port number in your app.
children.name: AWS_IOT_MQTT_PORT
children.title: AWS IoT MQTT Port

children.help:
Maximum MQTT transmit buffer size. This is the maximum MQTT
message length (including protocol overhead) which can be sent.

Sending longer messages will fail.
children.name: AWS_IOT_MQTT_TX_BUF_LEN
children.title: MQTT TX Buffer Length

children.help:
Maximum MQTT receive buffer size. This is the maximum MQTT
message length (including protocol overhead) which can be
received.

Longer messages are dropped.
children.name: AWS_IOT_MQTT_RX_BUF_LEN
children.title: MQTT RX Buffer Length

children.help: Maximum number of concurrent MQTT topic filters.
children.name: AWS_IOT_MQTT_NUM_SUBSCRIBE_HANDLERS
children.title: Maximum MQTT Topic Filters

children.help:
Initial delay before making first reconnect attempt, if the AWS IoT connection fails.
Client will perform exponential backoff, starting from this value.
children.name: AWS_IOT_MQTT_MIN_RECONNECT_WAIT_INTERVAL
children.title: Auto reconnect initial interval (ms)

children.help:
Maximum delay between reconnection attempts. If the exponentially increased delay
interval reaches this value, the client will stop automatically attempting to reconnect.
children.name: AWS_IOT_MQTT_MAX_RECONNECT_WAIT_INTERVAL
children.title: Auto reconnect maximum interval (ms)

children.help:
Allows setting a different Thing Shadow RX buffer size.
This is the maximum size of a Thing Shadow message in bytes,
plus one.
children.name: AWS_IOT_SHADOW_MAX_SIZE_OF_RX_BUFFER
children.title: Maximum RX Buffer (bytes)

children.help:
Allows setting a different Thing Shadow RX buffer
size. This is the maximum size of a Thing Shadow
message in bytes, plus one.

If not overridden, the default value is the MQTT RX Buffer length plus one. If overriden, do not set higher than the default value.
children.name: AWS_IOT_OVERRIDE_THING_SHADOW_RX_BUFFER
children.title: Override Shadow RX buffer size

children.help: Maximum size of the Unique Client Id.
children.name: AWS_IOT_SHADOW_MAX_SIZE_OF_UNIQUE_CLIENT_ID_BYTES
children.title: Maximum unique client ID size (bytes)

children.help: At any given time we will wait for this many responses. This will correlate to the rate at which the shadow actions are requested
children.name: AWS_IOT_SHADOW_MAX_SIMULTANEOUS_ACKS
children.title: Maximum simultaneous responses

children.help: We could perform shadow action on any thing Name and this is maximum Thing Names we can act on at any given time
children.name: AWS_IOT_SHADOW_MAX_SIMULTANEOUS_THINGNAMES
children.title: Maximum simultaneous Thing Name operations

children.help: These are the max tokens that is expected to be in the Shadow JSON document. Includes the metadata which is published
children.name: AWS_IOT_SHADOW_MAX_JSON_TOKEN_EXPECTED
children.title: Maximum expected JSON tokens

children.help: All shadow actions have to be published or subscribed to a topic which is of the format $aws/things/{thingName}/shadow/update/accepted. This refers to the size of the topic without the Thing Name
children.name: AWS_IOT_SHADOW_MAX_SHADOW_TOPIC_LENGTH_WITHOUT_THINGNAME
children.title: Maximum topic length (not including Thing Name)

children.help: Maximum length of a Thing Name.
children.name: AWS_IOT_SHADOW_MAX_SIZE_OF_THING_NAME
children.title: Maximum Thing Name length

children.help:
Select this option to enable support for the AWS IoT platform,
via the esp-idf component for the AWS IoT Device C SDK.
children.name: AWS_IOT_SDK
children.title: Amazon Web Services IoT Platform

children.help:
Specify the cpu core to run bluetooth controller.

When the maximum amount of device in the filter is reached, the cache will be refreshed.

Maximum number of adv packets which can be recorded in duplicate scan cache for BLE Mesh.
When the maximum amount of device in the filter is reached, the cache will be refreshed.
